This 5 day course with Indian clubs is a broad introduction to club swinging, designed to get you swinging correctly in the shortest amount of time.

The material for this course has been filmed as part of a live course we used to run.

We are going to look at single club swinging (referred to as ”closed style” and done with heavy clubs), and not the British ”open style” done with light clubs.

Both styles consist of very similar exercises, performed in slightly different ways, and you’ll have no problem switching from one to the other, according to the weight of the clubs you use.

Single club is the easiest style to learn, and the reason we chose it as the starting point.

One learns fastest by going from simple to complex skills!

Use a club around 1,5kg to 3 kg for the exercises. By all means, start light and assess.

Using Pahlavandle? Read our 6 tips.

After you have completed the 5 day course, you’ll have a basic understanding of the types of movements you can do with Indian clubs.

Please open and watch the videos in the right order to get the most out of this course.

You may chose to repeat a training day twice in a row, but we advise you from completing all the training in less than 5 days. We learn best in small, easy to digest servings. Do not rush the process!

What can Indian clubs do for you?

Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion

Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion

Consists of compound movements in multiple planes

Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise

Assists recovery from intense training

Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)

It is fun and you forget you are training.

The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.

Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ Heroic Sport | An ancient discipline

Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors and wrestlers.

Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.
